criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what an advance directive is and why people create them.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains components of advance directives (living will, healthcare power of attorney, POLST) and states why they are created—peace of mind and ensuring wishes are respected.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient and family ask their oncology team if there are resources available to assist in the creation of advance directives, such as social work.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises consulting with the oncologist and meeting with a palliative care specialist, directing the family to use the oncology team and associated resources to assist with planning, which fulfills the intent of the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should direct the patient to consider what medical treatments they would accept in the event of an emergency or if they became too sick to make decisions on their own, including wishes surrounding CPR, invasive medical procedures such as dialysis, artificial nutrition, and noninvasive medical treatments such as intravenous fluids or antibiotics. This is also referred to as a living will.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly lists resuscitation (DNR/CPR), mechanical ventilation, artificial nutrition/hydration, and dialysis, and frames this under a living will. While it does not name IV fluids/antibiotics specifically, it comprehensively covers the key treatment categories and context of a living will.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient elect a specific person to be their durable power of attorney for healthcare, or a person who would make medical decisions for them if they were too sick to make their own decisions.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes Healthcare Power of Attorney with explanation that this designates someone to make medical decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient should also complete a POLST, or a physician order for life-sustaining treatment, with their oncologist or other health practitioner, and should have this in their home in an easy-to-see location.
criterion_scores.justification: POLST/MOLST is mentioned, but the response does not instruct completing it with the oncologist or other clinician, nor does it advise keeping it in an easy-to-see location at home.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the advance directives should include a DNR order if desired.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly lists resuscitation preferences (DNR/CPR) as a key decision to address.

criterion_scores.description: The response should encourage patients to complete advance directives as soon as possible, even if their cancer is in remission or cured.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not encourage completing directives promptly or note the importance even if cancer is in remission or cured.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the logistics of completing an advance directive and recommend that the patient turn in a completed copy of the form to their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It provides practical steps (discuss with family/healthcare team, ensure legal validity in the state) and advises providing copies to healthcare providers, which includes the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize to patients with pancreatic cancer the importance of future planning, as this disease is difficult to cure and can be aggressive.
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes planning is important, it does not specifically emphasize the aggressive nature or poor curability of pancreatic cancer as a reason for early planning.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what an advance directive is and why people create them.
criterion_scores.justification: The response defines advance directives as important documents to ensure a loved one's wishes are honored and outlines their purpose, including specifying preferences and appointing decision-makers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient and family ask their oncology team if there are resources available to assist in the creation of advance directives, such as social work.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises consulting the oncologist and meeting with a social worker or chaplain, and notes that many hospitals have advance directive specialists, which aligns with recommending oncology team resources.

This is also referred to as a living will.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define what targeted therapy is in oncologic treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that targeted therapy uses drugs that specifically target cancer cells' unique features, contrasting with traditional chemotherapy that affects all rapidly dividing cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define cancer-related cachexia.

criterion_scores.justification: Advises keeping detailed notes about symptoms to share with the oncology team and encourages discussing symptoms with them, aligning with symptom reporting for management.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that chronic inflammation promotes tumor growth.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly says “Chronic inflammation can promote tumor growth and spread.”

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that inflammatory signaling pathways are overactivated in cancer (e.g., overactivated, upregulated, enhanced).
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions cancer-triggered inflammatory responses but does not state that signaling pathways are overactivated/upregulated/enhanced.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that the immune system can be activated to recognize and attack cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss leveraging or stimulating the immune system to attack cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that anti-inflammatory drugs are not used as a primary treatment for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions NSAIDs and corticosteroids but does not clarify that these are not primary/first-line treatments for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that NSAIDs and steroids are prescribed to manage symptoms associated with cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists NSAIDs and corticosteroids and mentions pain management, but does not explicitly state these drugs are used for symptom management/control.

criterion_scores.description: The response must clearly define inflammation using terms such as “immune response,” “tissue injury,” or “protective mechanism.”
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses effects of inflammation but does not define inflammation as an immune response to tissue injury or a protective mechanism.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly distinguish between acute and chronic inflammation, mentioning characteristics like “short-term” vs. “long-term” or “rapid onset” vs. “persistent.”
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions 'chronic inflammation' and 'steroids for acute inflammation,' it does not explicitly describe characteristics such as short-term vs. long-term or rapid vs. persistent.

criterion_scores.description: The response must describe at least two medical strategies for managing inflammation, such as “targeted therapies,” “immunotherapies,” “steroids,” or “pain management.”
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions steroids, COX-2 inhibitors, targeted therapies addressing inflammatory pathways, and pain management—meeting the requirement of at least two strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that there is no formal, evidence-based strategy to quantify and target inflammation in cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not state the absence of a formal, evidence-based strategy; it instead mentions monitoring inflammatory markers.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that treating the cancer itself, such as through “surgery” or “radiation,” is postulated to improve cancer-related inflammation.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention that definitive cancer treatments like surgery or radiation can reduce cancer-related inflammation.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention chronic pancreatitis or chronic pancreatic injury as a factor in cancer formation and provide at least one scientific reference with a PMID.
criterion_scores.justification: Chronic pancreatitis or pancreatic injury is not mentioned, and no scientific references or PMIDs are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend at least two lifestyle interventions to decrease inflammation, such as “plant-based diet,” “exercise,” “hydration,” or “good quality sleep.”
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends dietary adjustments, exercise, stress management, and adequate sleep—meeting the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend against nicotine and alcohol use and reference their role in promoting inflammation.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of avoiding nicotine or alcohol or their pro-inflammatory effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend that the patient report any symptoms to their oncology team for symptom management.
criterion_scores.justification: While it suggests discussing supplements/diet with the oncology team, it does not instruct reporting symptoms for symptom management.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that chronic inflammation promotes tumor growth. Synonyms for “promotes” include “supports,” “aids,” or “facilitates.”
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that chronic inflammation can 'promote cancer cell growth and spread.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that inflammatory signaling pathways are overactivated in cancer, using terms like “overactivated,” “upregulated,” or “enhanced.”
criterion_scores.justification: Although inflammatory pathways are mentioned, there is no explicit statement that they are overactivated/upregulated/enhanced in cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the immune system can be activated to recognize and attack cancer, using terms like “empower,” “stimulate,” or “leverage.”
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not state that the immune system can be activated to recognize and attack cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that anti-inflammatory drugs are not used as a primary treatment for pancreatic cancer. Synonyms for “primary” include “main” or “first-line.”
criterion_scores.justification: No statement clarifies that anti-inflammatory drugs are not first-line therapy for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that NSAIDs and steroids are prescribed to manage symptoms associated with cancer, using terms like “symptom management,” “symptom control,” or “alleviate symptoms.”
criterion_scores.justification: While steroids and COX-2 inhibitors are mentioned, the response does not explicitly link NSAIDs/steroids to symptom management or use the specified terminology.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention using a pill organizer with compartments for different times of the day and days of the week.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends "Weekly pill organizers with AM/PM compartments," which addresses both days (weekly) and times of day (AM/PM).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention using a medication management application, with examples such as Medisafe, MyTherapy, or CareZone.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists medication reminder apps and includes "Medisafe" by name, fulfilling the example requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention setting alarms or reminders on digital devices to alert when it’s time to take medication.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically recommends "Smartphone alarms with specific labels" and "Digital calendars with recurring reminders."

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention creating a physical chart or digital document listing all medications, dosages, and times.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions a "Medication chart posted in a visible location," "Medication tracking spreadsheets," and an "updated medication list," but does not explicitly state including dosages and times; thus it does not meet the full criterion as written.

criterion_scores.description: The response should direct the patient to discuss options for medication management with their oncology team and/or pharmacy team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises to "Ask about oncology pharmacy consultations" and to request simplified dosing, directing engagement with oncology/pharmacy teams.

criterion_scores.justification: Recommends "Set up pharmacy auto-refills and delivery" (delivery services) and "Pre-filled medication boxes from pharmacies," which corresponds to pharmacy-prepared bubble/blister packs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should empathize about the medication burden in patients undergoing cancer treatment.

criterion_scores.justification: Mentions "oncology pharmacy consultations" but does not specifically recommend meeting to perform a formal medication reconciliation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention using a medication management application, with examples such as Medisafe, MyTherapy, or CareZone.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention setting alarms or reminders on digital devices to alert when it’s time to take medication.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that medication apps 'send reminders and track doses,' which satisfies setting digital reminders.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention creating a physical chart or digital document listing all medications, dosages, and times.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends 'Wall charts or whiteboards,' 'Medication binders,' and tracking 'Medication names, dosages, and timing.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should direct the patient to discuss options for medication management with their oncology team and/or pharmacy team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises requesting a medication reconciliation sheet from the oncologist and consulting a clinical pharmacist; also mentions palliative care team coordination.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend exploring medication delivery services and bubble packs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient have a loved one help with their medication management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should empathize about the medication burden in patients undergoing cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathy and acknowledges the complexity and burden of managing pancreatic cancer medications.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention meeting with a pharmacist or provider to complete a medication reconciliation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define oncogenes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines oncogenes as genes that, when altered or overactive, can contribute to cancer development, and distinguishes proto-oncogenes from oncogenes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that oncogenes can undergo mutation, which might put the individual at risk for developing cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that mutations or overexpression convert proto-oncogenes into oncogenes that drive excessive cell growth, implying increased risk of cancer development.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how oncogenes mutate.
criterion_scores.justification: No mechanisms of alteration are described (e.g., point mutations, gene amplification, chromosomal translocation). The response only states that genes can be mutated or overexpressed without explaining how these changes occur.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference which mutated oncogenes are implicated in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists KRAS (mutated in ~90% of pancreatic cancers) and mentions HER2 and MYC, satisfying the requirement to reference oncogenes implicated in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state whether there are FDA-approved treatments available for pancreatic cancers with mutated oncogenes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response vaguely notes that some treatments target specific oncogenes but does not state whether FDA-approved treatments exist for pancreatic cancers with mutated oncogenes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients with pancreatic cancer undergo tumor genetic testing either with biopsy of primary tumor or blood test.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions genetic testing, it does not recommend that patients undergo tumor genomic testing specifically, nor does it specify biopsy-based or blood-based testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients inquire with their oncology team if there are clinical trial opportunities available to them, or a local institution.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of clinical trials or advising the patient to ask their oncology team about trial opportunities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define oncogenes.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines oncogenes as genes that, when altered or overactive, promote cancer, using the 'gas pedal' analogy and noting their normal role in controlled growth.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that oncogenes can undergo mutation, which might put the individual at risk for developing cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that mutations can make oncogenes overactive and drive uncontrolled growth, linking mutation to cancer development.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how oncogenes mutate.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not describe mechanisms of oncogene activation/mutation (e.g., point mutations, gene amplification, chromosomal translocations, promoter activation); only states that mutations can make them overactive and may increase protein levels.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference which mutated oncogenes are implicated in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Names KRAS (~90% of pancreatic cancers) and MYC, satisfying the requirement to reference oncogenes implicated in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state whether there are FDA-approved treatments available for pancreatic cancers with mutated oncogenes.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions targeted therapies in general but does not state whether FDA-approved treatments exist for oncogene-mutated pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients with pancreatic cancer undergo tumor genetic testing either with biopsy of primary tumor or blood test.
criterion_scores.justification: References genetic testing in a general sense but does not explicitly recommend tumor genomic testing or specify biopsy versus liquid biopsy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients inquire with their oncology team if there are clinical trial opportunities available to them, or a local institution.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of clinical trial opportunities or advising the patient to ask their oncology team about trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer is determined by the stage of the cancer and the intent of the treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly references stage (e.g., resectable, borderline resectable, advanced) but does not explicitly address treatment intent (curative vs palliative) as a determinant of sequencing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that sometimes pancreatic cancer management requires different modalities of treatments, such as chemotherapy and surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses surgery, chemotherapy (neoadjuvant and adjuvant), and also mentions radiation for advanced disease, clearly indicating multimodality treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that in pancreatic tumors thought to be surgically resectable, patients often undergo chemotherapy prior to surgery to shrink the tumor and kill any micrometastases for the best possible surgical outcome.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions neoadjuvant chemotherapy to shrink the tumor, it lists the most common resectable sequence as 'Surgery → chemotherapy' and does not state the micrometastatic rationale or that neoadjuvant is often used in resectable cases.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that surgery rarely plays a role in advanced pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: For advanced disease, it states 'Systemic chemotherapy first, with radiation considered later' but does not explicitly state that surgery rarely has a role.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer is.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains sequencing as the order/timing of therapies (e.g., operate first vs neoadjuvant chemo vs adjuvant chemo) and provides stage-based example sequences, effectively describing the concept.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the goal of treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It states goals such as shrinking the tumor preoperatively, eliminating residual cells postoperatively, preserving strength for subsequent therapies, and optimizing response to later treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state risks involved if cancer treatment is not appropriately sequenced.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it notes benefits of proper sequencing (tolerance, response), it does not explicitly state risks of improper sequencing (e.g., missing surgical window, disease progression, reduced ability to tolerate subsequent therapy).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient request a multidisciplinary conference to discuss their pancreatic cancer management recommendations.
criterion_scores.justification: No recommendation to request a multidisciplinary conference or tumor board is provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what a tumor board (or multidisciplinary conference) is for discussions on management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no description of a tumor board or multidisciplinary conference.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that the oncology care team needs to gather information to make informed recommendations on pancreatic cancer treatment, such as imaging studies, tumor biomarkers, and possibly tumor genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions considering 'specific genetic markers' but does not indicate the need to gather comprehensive information such as imaging studies or tumor biomarkers, nor does it frame this as necessary for making recommendations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize that treatment sequencing is individualized to the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: The statement 'Every patient's situation is unique' and consideration of overall health, tumor location, and genetic markers emphasize individualized sequencing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the following terms: neoadjuvant, adjuvant, perioperative.
criterion_scores.justification: Neoadjuvant and adjuvant are implicitly defined (chemo before surgery to shrink tumor; chemo after surgery to eliminate residual cells), but 'perioperative' is not mentioned or defined; the criterion requires definitions of all three.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer is determined by the stage of the cancer and the intent of the treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly ties sequencing to disease stage and resectability, but it does not explicitly address treatment intent (curative vs palliative), which is required.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that sometimes pancreatic cancer management requires different modalities of treatments, such as chemotherapy and surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly references surgery, neoadjuvant/adjuvant therapy, and systemic chemotherapy as modalities used in different sequences.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that in pancreatic tumors thought to be surgically resectable, patients often undergo chemotherapy prior to surgery to shrink the tumor and kill any micrometastases for the best possible surgical outcome.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes neoadjuvant therapy is increasingly used for resectable tumors and that chemotherapy first can shrink tumors in borderline resectable cases, but it does not state that resectable cases often receive preoperative chemo nor mention eradicating micrometastases.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that surgery rarely plays a role in advanced pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It says metastatic disease is typically treated with systemic therapy, but does not explicitly state that surgery rarely has a role in advanced disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer is.
criterion_scores.justification: By outlining surgery-first vs chemotherapy-first approaches and adjuvant/neoadjuvant timing, it effectively describes sequencing as the order in which treatments are given.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the goal of treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains goals: improving outcomes, reducing recurrence (adjuvant), and in advanced disease managing side effects and maintaining quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state risks involved if cancer treatment is not appropriately sequenced.
criterion_scores.justification: No explicit risks (e.g., loss of resectability window, increased toxicity, worse survival) are described.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient request a multidisciplinary conference to discuss their pancreatic cancer management recommendations.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends a specialist/center of excellence and a second opinion but does not suggest requesting a multidisciplinary conference or tumor board review.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what a tumor board (or multidisciplinary conference) is for discussions on management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention or description of a tumor board or multidisciplinary conference.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that the oncology care team needs to gather information to make informed recommendations on pancreatic cancer treatment, such as imaging studies, tumor biomarkers, and possibly tumor genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it mentions genetic markers (e.g., BRCA), it does not state the need to gather comprehensive diagnostic information like imaging, biomarkers, and genetic testing to guide sequencing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize that treatment sequencing is individualized to the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes the optimal order depends on multiple patient-specific factors, including performance status and patient preferences.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the following terms: neoadjuvant, adjuvant, perioperative.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines neoadjuvant (before surgery) and adjuvant (after surgery) but does not define perioperative.

criterion_scores.description: Define hypoxia as a low oxygen state often seen in tumors because the tumor outgrows its blood supply.
criterion_scores.justification: The response defines hypoxia as low oxygen and explains it occurs because tumors outgrow their blood supply, compress vessels, and form abnormal vasculature.

criterion_scores.description: Describe why cancer cells that exist in a hypoxic environment are difficult to treat.
criterion_scores.justification: It states hypoxia makes radiation less effective and reduces chemotherapy delivery due to poor blood flow, clearly explaining treatment difficulty.

criterion_scores.description: Describe how hypoxic environments affect cancer’s response to treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It directly addresses treatment response: hypoxia leads to radiation resistance and impairs chemotherapy penetration.

criterion_scores.description: State that radiation therapy becomes less effective in hypoxic conditions because oxygen plays a role in radiation-induced DNA damage.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes oxygen is needed to create DNA damage from radiation and that hypoxic areas are 2–3 times more resistant.

criterion_scores.description: Describe the mechanism of action of VEGF inhibitors and their postulated role in the treatment of hypoxic tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of VEGF inhibitors, anti-angiogenesis, or vascular normalization and their role in hypoxia.

criterion_scores.description: Explain whether there is evidence-based information about hyperbaric oxygen therapy in hypoxic tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is not discussed.

criterion_scores.description: Describe how hypoxic environments affect the immune system’s ability to access cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of immune infiltration, immunosuppression, or effects of hypoxia on immune access.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend discussing whether there are clinical trials focusing on tumor cell hypoxic environments available in their area.
criterion_scores.justification: The response encourages asking the care team questions but does not mention clinical trials targeting hypoxia.

criterion_scores.description: State that hypoxia can make the tumor more aggressive and promote metastasis (spread).
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states hypoxia can make tumors more aggressive and more likely to spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define hypoxia as a low oxygen state often seen in tumors because the tumor outgrows its blood supply.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines hypoxia as low oxygen in tumors and explains it occurs when cancer growth outpaces blood supply.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe why cancer cells that exist in a hypoxic environment are difficult to treat.
criterion_scores.justification: States hypoxic areas make tumors more aggressive and harder to treat and that hypoxic cells are more resistant to radiation and some chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how hypoxic environments affect cancer’s response to treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes reduced effectiveness of radiation in hypoxia and variable chemotherapy efficacy; mentions imaging to identify hypoxia and combination approaches to overcome resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that radiation therapy becomes less effective in hypoxic conditions because oxygen plays a role in radiation-induced DNA damage.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions radiation may be less effective in hypoxic areas but does not explain that oxygen is required to fix radiation-induced DNA damage.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the mechanism of action of VEGF inhibitors and their postulated role in the treatment of hypoxic tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of VEGF inhibitors, anti-angiogenesis, or vascular normalization in hypoxic tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain whether there is evidence-based information about hyperbaric oxygen therapy in hypoxic tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address hyperbaric oxygen therapy or evidence for/against its use in tumor hypoxia.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how hypoxic environments affect the immune system’s ability to access cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of immune exclusion, impaired immune cell infiltration, or hypoxia-driven immunosuppression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient discuss whether there are clinical trials focusing on tumor cell hypoxic environments available in their area.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages asking about clinical trials addressing hypoxia and hypoxia-targeting therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that hypoxia can make the tumor more aggressive and promote metastasis (spread).
criterion_scores.justification: States tumors can be more aggressive but does not mention metastasis or spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient request a language interpreter if they feel more comfortable communicating in an alternate language than what their medical team speaks.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient bring a loved one or family member to all appointments and consider taking notes or recording the conversation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient request a language interpreter if they feel more comfortable communicating in an alternate language than what their medical team speaks.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define cancer cell plasticity.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines plasticity as the ability of cancer cells to change characteristics and shift between states, using an accessible analogy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cell plasticity makes cancer cells more difficult to treat.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains treatment resistance, shifts between proliferative and dormant states, and acquisition of stem-like properties that reduce sensitivity to therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the epithelial-mesenchymal transition in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention EMT or its relevance to pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role plasticity plays in the metastatic potential of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of metastasis or how plasticity facilitates invasion or dissemination.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define and describe cancer cell dormancy.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies dormancy as a state where cells are not actively dividing and may survive treatment, which is a basic definition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cell plasticity can contribute to cancer cell dormancy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that plasticity enables switching between active and dormant states.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cell plasticity allows cancer cells to evade the immune system, making immunotherapy relatively ineffective.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of immune evasion or immunotherapy response in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention ways that cancer-directed therapy can be used to attempt to overcome cancer cell plasticity, such as treatment sequencing and medication combinations.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses combination therapies, sequencing, monitoring, and adapting plans in response to resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that therapeutic strategies to target plasticity is an active area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes that newer approaches targeting plasticity are being studied in clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define cancer cell plasticity.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines plasticity as the ability of cancer cells to change characteristics and behavior, including switching states, altering metabolism, and changing responses—meets definition requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cell plasticity makes cancer cells more difficult to treat.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains treatment resistance and changing molecular targets that reduce efficacy, and notes rationale for combination therapies—adequately links plasticity to treatment difficulty.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the epithelial-mesenchymal transition in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT) or its role in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role plasticity plays in the metastatic potential of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that plastic cancer cells may be better at spreading and adapting to new environments, directly linking plasticity to metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define and describe cancer cell dormancy.
criterion_scores.justification: Dormancy is not mentioned or defined.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cell plasticity can contribute to cancer cell dormancy.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion connecting plasticity to dormancy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cell plasticity allows cancer cells to evade the immune system, making immunotherapy relatively ineffective.
criterion_scores.justification: No explanation of immune evasion or why immunotherapy may be less effective in pancreatic cancer due to plasticity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention ways that cancer-directed therapy can be used to attempt to overcome cancer cell plasticity, such as treatment sequencing and medication combinations.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions combination therapies, monitoring tumor changes, and adjusting treatment plans—meets the criterion for strategies to address plasticity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that therapeutic strategies to target plasticity is an active area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state that targeting plasticity is an active area of research.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define mechanical forces in relation to cancer cells, explicitly mentioning “physical forces” or “pressure.”
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly mentions mechanical forces and explicitly references “pressure,” “high pressure inside tumors,” and “mechanical stress,” clearly defining mechanical forces in this context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the effect of different mechanical forces on cancer growth and proliferation, including the activation of pathways or signaling pathways.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that high pressure promotes aggressive behavior, impedes drug penetration, and that mechanical stress can “trigger signals” aiding survival and spread; it also mentions “mechanical signaling pathways,” satisfying the signaling requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define desmoplastic stroma, which is often seen in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes a “dense, fibrous shell (called desmoplasia) that makes the tumor very stiff,” effectively capturing the concept of desmoplastic stroma characteristic of pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the pancreatic cancer tumor microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses key TME features, including dense fibrotic stroma, stiffness, compression of vessels/ducts/nerves, and consequences like impaired drug penetration and altered blood flow.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention future research directions as it pertains to desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It cites ongoing research to reduce tumor stiffness, target mechanical signaling pathways, and understand how mechanical forces drive treatment resistance, directly addressing desmoplastic stroma research directions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain if there are FDA approved therapies that act on the desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It does not address whether any FDA-approved therapies specifically target the desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that in pancreatic cancer, the stroma is very dense and stiff, leading to high interstitial pressure and reduced oxygen and nutrient delivery.
criterion_scores.justification: While it states the stroma is dense and stiff and mentions high pressure, it does not explicitly mention “interstitial” pressure nor reduced oxygen and nutrient delivery.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the dense stroma can impede treatment delivery and induce hypoxia, explicitly mentioning “hypoxia” and “treatment resistance.”
criterion_scores.justification: It notes impaired drug penetration and mentions “treatment resistance,” but it does not explicitly mention “hypoxia,” which is required.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the dense stroma can impede immune cells from reaching the tumor, explicitly mentioning “immune evasion” or “reduced efficacy of immunotherapy.”
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of immune cell exclusion, immune evasion, or reduced efficacy of immunotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define mechanical forces in relation to cancer cells, explicitly mentioning “physical forces” or “pressure.”

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the effect of different mechanical forces on cancer growth and proliferation, including the activation of pathways or signaling pathways.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define senescence in cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines senescence as permanent cessation of cell division with continued metabolic activity, using an accurate and accessible analogy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe senescence-associated secretory phenotype factors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of senescence in normal cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways in which cancer cells evade senescence.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how cancer cells detect mechanical characteristics of their environment.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how fluid flow becomes compromised in tumors, including increased intratumoral pressure due to abnormal blood vessels, poor lymphatic drainage, and dense stroma.

criterion_scores.description: The response clearly explains how changes in tissue density and architecture (cell jamming) influence cancer cell movement, tumor aggressiveness, and metastasis.
